abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and the institutional development
            impact is substantial. Lessons reinforce that while
            ownership, and commitment by the Borrower is crucial, it
            remains difficult to ascertain these two factors, beyond the
            needed funds. One way to maximize these two factors, could
            be by minimizing staff changes, on both the Bank and
            Borrower sides, but involving greater number of people on
            the borrower's side in project preparation, through
            workshops, and other means of information, to reduce
            dependence on few key staff members, and gain support for
            project objectives, regardless of the fact that project
            preparation may become more time consuming, and expensive.
            Moreover, coordination of action plans by a number of
            agencies does become cumbersome; rather, commitments on a
            few agreed-upon actions by a few agencies, instead of a
            myriad, disconnected actions by many agencies, would be
            simpler, and should make possible to match the
            country's, and implementing agencies' objectives,
            with the Bank's strategic objectives. Further lessons
            suggest the need for an early agreement on procurement
            procedures; to ensure implementation of a strong financial
            management; to ensure that terms of reference reflect the
            needs of the agency, and its management capability; and, to
            ensure flexibility, and relevance in the design of capacity
            building programs.

1948549.trustfund:
TF021251-PHRD-JAPANESE CTF (USD ACCOUNT),TF020761-AUSTRALIAN CONSULTANTS TRUST
            FUND (USD)

abstracts.cdata!:
With the general objective of meeting
            the continued rapid growth in transport demand resulting
            from sustained economic growth, and to address critical
            issues associated with the transport-related environmental
            pollution and traffic safety, the Fifth Highway Sector
            Project aims specifically at: 1) furthering the
            implementation of actions aimed at reducing environmental
            degradation and vehicular accidents attributable to fast
            growing motorization through the establishment of a
            privately operated vehicle inspection system; 2) improving
            the quality of service of the inter-urban road network
            through increased road capacity and improved safety
            standards of existing roads; and 3) providing a systematic
            basis for the establishment of environmental assessment
            criteria at the design stage as well as environmental
            management during and after new road construction and
            capacity increases. The project will finance the following
            components over a period of about four years: 1) civil works
            sub-projects for capacity increases involving the widening
            to four lanes and rehabilitation of the existing two lanes
            of selected sections of the country's major inter-urban
            national highways; 2) consulting services for the design and
            supervision of the Department of Highways' (DOH) road
            widening program; 3) technical assistance and training to
            the Land Transport Department, the Department of Pollution
            Control, DOH and the Ministry of Transport and
            Communications related to air quality, highway safety
            improvements, and institutional development; and 4)
            strengthening environmental assessment and mitigation
            management capacities at DOH and the Office of Environmental
            Policy and Planning.

732868.trustfund:
TF021251-PHRD-JAPANESE CTF (USD ACCOUNT),TF020761-AUSTRALIAN CONSULTANTS TRUST
            FUND (USD)

repnme.cdata!:
Thailand - Fifth Highway Sector Loan :
            sectoral environmental assessment for highways

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fifth Highway Sector Project sets
            out to: 1) improve Thailand's major inter-city raodways
            by widening to 4-lane standards; 2) resurface and restore
            existing roads to allow them to carry increasing traffic and
            heavier vehicles; 3) provide technical assistance and
            trainng; and 4) support the procurement of various related
            types of equipment for the Ministry of Transport and
            Communications and other agencies.  The major environmental
            issues associated with the project are
            transportation-related air pollution and noise, and the
            potential for involuntary resettlement of people along or
            within the existing inter-city roadway.   The sectoral
            environmental assessment is primarily aimed at describing
            the environmental documentation requirements, legal and
            regulatory framework, and the institutional capabilities of
            affected agencies.  Suggestions are made for warrented
            project definition and screening procedural changes,
            mitigation planning, training, and other institutional
            aspects of the environmental assessment process.
